title:
Probing Heavy Axion-like Particles from Massive Stars with X-rays and
  Gamma Rays
authors: James H. Buckley, P. S. Bhupal Dev, Francesc Ferrer, and Takuya Okawa
abstract:
The hot interiors of massive stars in the later stages of their evolution
provide an ideal place for the production of heavy axion-like particles (ALPs)
with mass up to O(100 keV) range. We show that a fraction of these ALPs could
stream out of the stellar photosphere and subsequently decay into two photons
that can be potentially detected on or near the Earth. In particular, we
estimate the photon flux originating from the spontaneous decay of heavy ALPs
produced inside Horizontal Branch and Wolf-Rayet stars, and assess its
detectability by current and future $X$-ray and gamma-ray telescopes. Our
results indicate that current and future telescopes can probe axion-photon
couplings down to $g_{a\gamma} \sim 4\times 10^{-11}$ GeV${}^{-1}$ for $m_a\sim
10-100$ keV, which covers new ground in the ALP parameter space.
